column31: So far, you have named the features that define a high-quality unit test. In the last part of this survey, we ask you to consider those features to rate unit tests.  You will be presented with three randomly chosen unit tests and will be asked to rate the quality of the given unit test (1) overall and (2) with respect to the features you previously mentioned.     The following 3 pages are structured as follows:  You will be presented two code snippets per page: On the left side a unit test, and on the right side the corresponding class under test, which may help you in your judgement. Additionally, you will also be given test metrics such as mutation and line coverage below the code snippets. To rate the test cases, you will see two matrices on the bottom of the page: One to rate the overall quality of the given unit test, and one for the rating according to the features you named before.     All the code snippets used in this survey are from the Java open source project apache/commons-lang.

column20: Some tests try to test multiple things at once and become large, for the sake of removing duplication. It is better to split these into multiple small tests.

column28: Running one test is the same as running multiple tests. There is no cross-talk between them.
column30: Why the test is there is apparent. The test serves a purpose, correlated with software requirements.

column20: Thought using the driver/navigator setup. I first describe the specification of the code as a navigator to keep high level goals clean and defined, then I switch for the easier role by driving the implementation. The mental model limitations of a human brain cause problem if the two role mixed at the same time.

column145:
Most engineers are bad at writing unit tests, and often end up with tests that are too brittle or don't actually catch regressions. Neither mutation coverage nor code coverage accurately represents whether a test suite is good. 

Integration tests tend to be more valuable than unit tests as they can better demonstrate: 1) what is a system supposed to be doing and 2) whether or not the system is still able to do that. 

The workflow around unit tests is super important. If engineers have to think about running tests, than they likely won't. Tooling should make tests disappear --- the tests should "just work" without requiring too much additional setup.

Having a CI/CD system that rejects commits which breaks tests is an important part of maintaining high quality tests.

column9: High coverage of code/system under test
column20: Test grinding. The same code with the same test must always yield the same result.
column24: Code coverage calculation

column9: Tells the reader what a test failure means

column7: Meaningful. Do not just test is an outcome is not null.
column8: Descriptive. Another developer should be able to tell what the test is about by reading the unit test.
column9: Clean. This is for maintainability. Unit tests are for preventing regressions so it is important that these tests can be read and understood easily.
verify true expectation, not implementation details
column10: not require architectural changes to the code under test
column22: Number of assert invocations per method

column7: Simplicity, tests one thing at a time
column8: Easily understandable, expected output for an input should be very clear
column20: We don't formally measure it, we try to maintain it through pull requests

column8: Should verify the tested code, not just verify other attributes of the unit test in a way that appears to verify the code
column9: Should fail when code changes in a way that makes the code defective, rather than failing because the code was changed at all
column10: ...be executed in a gated commit or nightly build so that developers don't break them
column12: Have high real usefulness / ability to detect defects in the application

column142: Firmware/software engineer working on touchscreen hemodynamic monitoring devices

column20: By how neatly and concisely code is written, how idiomatic it is, and how well properties / variables are named.
column26: How many tests fail and how many are ignored are important but it should go without saying that high coverage with passing unit tests is important
column145: No, but an interesting survey. It was good that you provided examples but it would have been better if the examples were more easy to understand - then we can imagine what it would be like to actually run that test.

column8: limited in scope (test only one case, one behaviour)
column9: justifiable (explain what is being tested and why it should behave that way)
column10: economical (there will be many tests; they must be fast)
column11: pragmatic (prioritize the common and important cases; consider cost of testing to cost of missing)
column20: We run continuous integration testing. If a test is found to fail randomly, we investigate why and change it to be reproducible.
column22: We perform code reviews of both production code and test code. If tests are seen to test too many things at once, we encourage developers to break them up into smaller tests.
column24: We perform code reviews of production code and unit test code. If is isn't clear what a test is testing, or why the behaviour it tests should be correct, we encourage developers to add explanations to the tests.
column26: Every test is timed. If the total runtime of the test suite is too large, we look at the longest running tests and try to find ways to speed them up. Sometimes that means testing those aspects less often, such as once a day instead of once on every change/commit.
column145: I think it is useful to look at how developers perceive unit testing, in terms of its purpose, its importance, the qualities it should have, and the quality of testing in their own and others' projects. But I think this is most valuable when contrasted against research on what actually works and what benefits it actually provides. Regardless of why or how we think we should be writing tests, those tests are only valuable if they help us to achieve our goals. If our beliefs and practices don't actually provide the benefits they seek, then we should aim to change our perceptions and change our habits. I have seen many people look at one side of this question or the other, but I don't know of any attempt to compare the two and see if our behaviours actually give the intended benefits.

column10: Test speciality states such as order, uniqueness, etc
column12: Have meaningful names so that erroneous code is located quickly and fixed
column24: We have a timer that runs during testing and we can check the output log of the tests or the length of runtime in our build pipeline.
column26: We make assertions during tests to test uniqueness and ordering in certain functions. Test cases will fail if the order is incorrect or the multiples exist in functions which are supposed to follow these conventions.
column28: Some projects I've worked on have specific tests for normal use (usually named nominal) and error use (usually named off_nominal). This is to determine that appropriate failures are displayed (such as exceptions) or backup systems engage properly to handle the errors.
column30: We work with pytest, so usually our test cases match the name of our modules prepended with test_. So the do_thing.py will have a test class called test_do_thing.py so the pytest discovery properly locates the test cases. We also usually will name the tests after the function/class names in the module so that erroneous code can be isolated and quickly found.

column8: Capture the user requirement. Yes. You read that correctly. Unit tests should ensure the unit works along with the user requirements.  If the test breaks (after some time), it means that the code has regressed or a conflicting  user requirement has creeped into the scope.

column145: Evaluation Java code samples is a major pita. Most probably this unreadable mess is perfectly fine and accepted best practice in the Java (or generally imperative, inheritance based object oriented programming) world. It is basically impossible to decide on the "quality" of such unit tests when "unit" is used as a synonym to "method" and the only specification for the correct working of a method is crippled Javadoc. I doubt my answers have any relevancy here.

column7: independent of the underyling implementation as much as possible.
column8: easy to setup and read by someone maintaining the code.
column9: clear in its intent such that the reader must not be confused should the test fail whether the test needs changing or a defect was introduced in code.
column10: independent of other unit tests such that modifying the scenario of another test should not impact another.
column11: possibly reflecting a real world scenario such that one could debug the test to understand the underlying logic in relation to the expected results.
column12: deterministic and environment or time independent such that it should not fail when run on a different setup/culture/day and, if that is the case, must explicitely include them in the setup.
